Question: The protein clathrin is involved in all of the following EXCEPT:
OptionC: Sorting of proteins in the Golgi apparatus
Explanation:
Correct: E. Protein synthesis
Why? Clathrin forms the protein “coat” of clathrin-coated pits/vesicles, enabling membrane budding and cargo selection during endocytosis and Golgi–endosome trafficking.
  • A, B, D: classic clathrin functions in vesicle formation and receptor-mediated endocytosis.
  • C: clathrin participates in trafficking from the trans-Golgi network to endosomes.
  • E is wrong because protein synthesis occurs on ribosomes (free or RER-bound), not via clathrin.

Question: The mesoderm is generated by:
Explanation:
Correct: B. Epiblast
Mechanism: During gastrulation, epiblast cells migrate through the primitive streak:
  • First wave replaces hypoblast → definitive endoderm
  • Next wave spreads between layers → intraembryonic mesoderm
  • Remaining epiblast → ectoderm
Exam tip: All three germ layers derive from epiblast.

Question: From which germ layer originates the adenohypophysis (anterior pituitary)?
Explanation:
Correct: C. Surface ectoderm
The adenohypophysis develops from Rathke’s pouch, an upward outgrowth of the oral ectoderm (surface ectoderm).
  • Posterior pituitary (neurohypophysis) is from neuroectoderm (diencephalon) — common distractor.

Question: Which cells are generated by the secondary spermatocytes?
Explanation:
Correct: C. Early spermatids
Sequence: Primary spermatocyte (2n) → Meiosis I → secondary spermatocyte (n) → Meiosis II → spermatids (n).
  • Spermatozoa form later by spermiogenesis (maturation of spermatids), not directly from secondary spermatocytes.

Question: Which of the following phases of the menstrual cycle is under progesterone control?
Explanation:
Correct: D. Secretory phase
Progesterone from the corpus luteum converts the estrogen-primed endometrium into a secretory, implantation-ready lining.
  • Proliferative/Follicular phase is mainly estrogen-driven.
  • Progesterone withdrawal → endometrial shedding → menstruation.

Question: A sperm sample is considered to have normal morphology when:
OptionA: At least 4% of sperm are normal
OptionB: At least 10% of sperm are normal
OptionC: At least 12% of sperm are normal
OptionD: If 14% or more of the observed sperm are normal
OptionE: If all sperm are morphologically identical
Explanation:
Correct: D. If 14% or more of the observed sperm are normal
Many exam keys (including older WHO-style teaching) use ≥14% normal forms as the threshold for “normal morphology.”
Note: Some modern “strict” criteria use lower cutoffs, but follow the exam’s stated key.

Question: What is the shape of the nucleus of a typical cardiomyocyte?
Explanation:
Correct: D. Oval
  • Typical cardiomyocyte: 1 central oval nucleus (sometimes 2).
  • Skeletal muscle: many peripheral nuclei.
  • Neutrophils: segmented nuclei (classic distractor).

Question: Match the germ layers and their respective tissue derivatives:
Explanation:
Correct: B. Intermediate mesoderm ⇒ Gonads
Intermediate mesoderm forms the urogenital ridge → kidneys + gonads and their ducts.
  • Paraxial mesoderm → somites → skeletal muscle, vertebrae, dermis (not epidermis).
  • Ectoderm → epidermis + nervous system (not kidneys).
  • Endoderm → epithelial lining of gut/respiratory tract (not skeletal muscle).

Question: All of the following answers are true EXCEPT: Microtubules can be localized:
Explanation:
Correct: E. In microvilli
Microvilli are supported by actin filaments (microfilaments), not microtubules.
  • Cilia/flagella: microtubule axoneme (9+2).
  • Centrosome/mitotic spindle: microtubule organizing and spindle formation.

Question: What type of cell junction is the focal adhesion?
Explanation:
Correct: D. Cell–matrix junction
Focal adhesions link actin filaments inside the cell to the extracellular matrix via integrins and adaptor proteins (e.g., talin, vinculin).
Contrast: Desmosomes are cell–cell junctions linked to intermediate filaments.
